body.p: It is known that 4% of children carry a certain virus, but a leading health researcher suspects that the percentage is actually higher. Which of the following provides the most convincing evidence to support the researcher’s suspicion?

input.choice: Out of 20 randomly chosen children, 1 child carries the virus.
Out of 60 randomly chosen children, 3 children carry the virus.
Out of 5,000 randomly chosen children, 250 children carry the virus.
Out of 5,000 randomly chosen children, 210 children carry the virus.

response.feedback: Incorrect. While it is true that 1/20 = 0.05 = 5% is larger than 4%, recall that the more repetitions that are performed, the closer the relative frequency gets to the probability it estimates. There is another option that provides more convincing evidence.

Incorrect. While it is true that 3/60 = 0.05 = 5% is larger than 4%, recall that the more repetitions that are performed, the closer the relative frequency gets to the probability it estimates. There is another option that provides more convincing evidence.
Correct. The relative frequency of children carrying the virus is 250/5,000 = 5% which is larger than 4% and has the largest number of repetitions.
Incorrect. While it is true that the relative frequency of children carrying the virus is 210/5,000 = 0.042 is larger than 4%, there is another option that provides more convincing evidence.

body.p: It is known that roughly 5% of the general population carry a certain virus. A health researcher believes that among caucasian males the percentage is actually lower. Which of the following will provide the most convincing evidence to support the researcher’s suspicion?

input.choice: Out of 25 randomly chosen caucasian males, 1 male carries the virus.
Out of 70 randomly chosen caucasian males, 3 males carry the virus.
Out of 6,000 randomly chosen caucasian males, 288 males carry the virus.
Out of 6,000 randomly chosen caucasian males, 240 males carry the virus.

response.feedback: Incorrect. While it is true that 1/25 = 0.04 = 4% is smaller than 5%, recall that the more repetitions that are performed, the closer the relative frequency gets to the probability it estimates. There is another option that provides more convincing evidence to support the researcher’s suspicion.

Incorrect. While it is true that 3/50 = 0.043 = 4.3% is smaller than 5%, recall that the more repetitions that are performed, the closer the relative frequency gets to the probability it estimates. There is another option that provides more convincing evidence.

Incorrect. While it is true that the relative frequency of caucasian males carrying the virus is 288/6,000 = 0.048 = 4.8% is less than 5%, there is another option that provides more convincing evidence.
Correct. The relative frequency of caucasian males carrying the virus is 240/6,000 = 0.04 = 4% which is less than 5%.

body.p: Suppose Joan has a fair four-sided die with sides that are numbered 1, 2, 3, and 4.
Image attribution: CC BY NC 3.0 by CK-12
After she rolls it 20 times, Joan finds that she’s rolled the number 3 six times. What is the empirical probability that Joan rolls a 3?

response.feedback: Incorrect. You may have selected this choice because Joan rolled a 3 six times. However, we would need to take into account how many times Joan attempted to roll the die.
Incorrect. You may have selected this choice because Joan rolled the die 20 times. However, we would need to take into account how many times Joan rolled a 3 to compute the empirical probability.

Incorrect. You may have selected this choice because it is the theoretical probability of rolling a 3. Indeed, of the 4 different equally likely outcomes, this is one of them (1/4 = 25%). However, this is not the empirical probability that Joan demonstrated.
Correct. In six of the 20 different attempts, Joan rolled a 3. So the probability is 6/20 = 30%.

body.p: Suppose Joan has a fair four-sided die with sides that are numbered 1, 2, 3, and 4.
Image attribution: CC BY NC 3.0 by CK-12
After she rolls it 20 times, how many times does she roll the number 3?

response.feedback: Incorrect. While it is possible that the number 3 will appear three times, we do not know that this is what will happen when Joan rolls the die.

Incorrect. You may have selected this choice because the probability of rolling a 3 is 25%, and 25% of 20 is 5. However, while this is the most likely number of times Joan will roll a 3, we do not know that this is what will happen.
Incorrect. While it is possible that the number 3 will appear three times, we do not know that this is what will happen when Joan rolls the die.

Correct. While we may be able to compute the theoretical probability of rolling a 3, we can’t use that information to determine how often a 3 actually appears when Joan (or anyone else for that matter) rolls the die.

body.p: Suppose Joan has a fair four-sided die with sides that are numbered 1, 2, 3, and 4.
Image attribution: CC BY NC 3.0 by CK-12
After she rolls it 2,000 times, she finds that she rolled the number 2 a total of 187 times. Which of the following is true?

input.choice: Joan has demonstrated that this is a fair die, since the relative frequency of rolling a 2 is nearly equal to the theoretical probability.

Joan has provided evidence that calls into question whether or not this is a fair die because the relative frequency of rolling a 2 is quite different than the theoretical probability even after repeating the experiment many times.
We cannot draw any conclusions from Joan’s experience with this die because there is only a very weak link between the relative frequency of an event and the theoretical probability.
We cannot draw any conclusions from Joan’s experience with this die without also knowing how many times the other numbers appeared.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The theoretical probability of rolling a 2 is 1/4 = 25%, while Joan’s experience has the relative frequency at 187/2,000 = 9.35%. Joan’s experience includes a large number of trials so the Law of Large Numbers would suggest that the theoretical and empirical probabilities should be similar. Since these numbers are not too similar, it would not be appropriate to use Joan’s experience as evidence that the die is fair.

Correct. The theoretical probability of rolling a 2 is 1/4 = 25%, while Joan’s experience has the relative frequency at 187/2,000 = 9.35%, which is quite different. Joan’s experience includes a large number of trials so the Law of Large Numbers would suggest that the theoretical and empirical probabilities should be similar. Therefore, her experience does call into question the die as possibly not being fair.
Incorrect. With 2,000 trials, Joan’s experience includes a large number of trials so the Law of Large Numbers would suggest that the theoretical and empirical probabilities should be similar.

Incorrect. While knowing the number of times other numbers appeared would potentially add additional ways in which the die may not be fair, it is not necessary to know the other values to make a conclusion. With 2,000 trials, Joan’s experience includes a large number of trials so the Law of Large Numbers would suggest that the theoretical and empirical probabilities should be similar.
